reporting-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

title.narrative: Use of SMART conservation software to combat illegal hunting of Silky Sifaka lemurs (Propithecus candidus) in Makira Natural Park, Madagascar

description.narrative: This project will reduce hunting pressures on Silky Sifaka within the Makira Natural Park. Specific objectives include: (1) Improve capacity of Park staff and local communities to implement law enforcement monitoring; (2) Implement a tailored LEM / SMART system and use the results to develop management actions to stem illegal hunting.

participating-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

participating-org.usg:office-name: Fish and Wildlife Service/Office of International Affairs

owner-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

description.narrative: The U.S. government seeks to help Madagascar consolidate its democratic gains and begin addressing the root causes of poverty, which leave it ranked as one of the poorest countries in the world. According to the World Bank, more than 92 percent of Madagascar's population survives on less than two dollars a day and 77 percent live in extreme poverty. U.S. assistance will provide support in the areas of environment, democracy and good governance, and peace and security. Continued investments in health and food security activities will build upon successes and accelerate progress towards ending preventable child and maternal deaths, preventing malaria, as well as promoting a stable, resilient Malagasy society.

usg:treasury-account.usg:main-account: Resource Management, United States Fish and Wildlife Service
